Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2013 06:13AM chipmunk57 wrote: just got my date. mastectomy & sentinel node biopsy on Wednesday, Nov. 27th. Glad the waiting is over. Well, almost
Posts.Title: November 2013 surgeries mimi32 MCbeach

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2013 09:31AM chipmunk57 wrote: Surgery went well yesterday. W00t! Home yesterday with 2 drains. Very little pain, no nausea. I <3 my anesthesiologist! He told me he would mix me a 3 drug cocktail and it worked! Unlike the last time I had surgery and threw up for 3 days. A little concerned about my pre-surgery MRI. The left side was clear but they found an additional small spot in the right breast which the radiologist said could be a satellite tumor or a positive lymph node. I had a MX planned anyway so that didn't change anything. Also, one lymph node in the armpit showed a little activity. If more nodes turn up positive from the SNB I may need an axillary node dissection. So now I am waiting on the path report, just when I thought all the waiting for bad news was over. Oh well, fingers crossed. Hope all is going well for everyone else this week!
Posts.Title: November 2013 surgeries mimi32 MCbeach

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2013 01:27PM chipmunk57 wrote: Spoomsis, I was just diagnosed two days before you, on Monday. My story is very similar to yours: noticed a "dent" under my right nipple when I pulled off my sports bra but couldn't feel a lump. This was on Oct 3rd. Saw my family doc the next day, she said she felt "something" but it wasn't well-defined. She set up a diagnostic mammogram for Oct 18. At the hospital, they sent me directly from the mammo to ultrasound. When the radiologist was doing the U/S she said she felt a "smoothness" under the dent and wanted to do a biopsy. Biopsied on Oct 22nd (hurt like hell!) and my family doctor called me in on Monday to tell me I have breast cancer. Yesterday my husband & I went to see my breast surgeon. I will be having a simple mastectomy with sentinel node biopsy, probably in about two weeks. My tumor is fairly large and my breasts are small, so it didn't make sense to have a partial, she would have to remove 90% of my breast anyway to get good margins. Anyway, just wanted to say best of luck to you, and we will get through this!
Posts.Title: Found breast tethering while fixing my hair. :o( Spoomsister Roxybabes
Found breast tethering while fixing my hair. :o( Spoomsister Roxybabes

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2013 11:56AM chipmunk57 wrote: Spoomsister, I hear you about the mood swings, lol! Most of the time I manage to be pretty upbeat and positive, but last night all of a sudden I just got scared about everything - surgery, chemo, dying, ... I had a good cry and hugs from hubby. Today I am back at work and pretty much under control again, but I just got a call telling me my MRI is scheduled for next Wednesday, the 13th (hope that's not an omen!). It's starting to get real now, and I might have to get off the banks of that river in Egypt soon. Take care.
Posts.Title: Found breast tethering while fixing my hair. :o( Spoomsister Roxybabes

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2013 05:17PM chipmunk57 wrote: 2bluestars, I had my drains pulled a week ago. It was WONDERFUL!!! The pain you feel when moving, etc, is mainly from the stitches pulling your skin. They clip the stitches and pull the drains. It hardly hurt at all. It feels kind of weird because you can feel the drains coming out, but I felt 100%better afterwards. I'm really bummed that I have to get another drain when I have my node dissection next week, but my surgeon said it will probably only be in for 48 hours. Hope so!
Posts.Title: December 2013 surgeries bobogirl sandra4611

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2013 07:44PM chipmunk57 wrote: Hi everyone. Looks like I am joining the Dec surgery club as well, after my mastectomy on Nov 27th. Found out today that one of the sentinel nodes was positive so I am having axillary node dissection on Dec. 18th. At least I will get it over with before Christmas. I hope those of you who have already had their surgery are healing well, and good luck to those with upcoming surgery. Take care everyone!
